Class Vector

Miquel Sas

    divergenceJensenShannon(double[] x, double[] y)
    Jensen-Shannon divergence JS(P||Q) = (KL(P||M) + KL(Q||M)) / 2, where M = (P+Q)/2.The Jensen-Shannon divergence is a popular method of measuring the similarity between two probability distributions.It is also known as information radius or total divergence to the average.It is based on the Kullback-Leibler divergence, with the difference that it is always a finite value.
    static double
    divergenceKullbackLeibler(double[] x, double[] y)
    Kullback-Leibler divergence.The Kullback-Leibler divergence (also information divergence, information gain, relative entropy, or KLIC) is a non-symmetric measure of the difference between two probability distributions P and Q.KL measures the expected number of extra bits required to code samples from P when using a code based on Q, rather than using a code based on P.Typically P represents the "true" distribution of data, observations, or a precise calculated theoretical distribution.

    • divergenceJensenShannon

      public static double divergenceJensenShannon(double[] x, double[] y)
      Jensen-Shannon divergence JS(P||Q) = (KL(P||M) + KL(Q||M)) / 2, where M = (P+Q)/2.The Jensen-Shannon divergence is a popular method of measuring the similarity between two probability distributions.It is also known as information radius or total divergence to the average.It is based on the Kullback-Leibler divergence, with the difference that it is always a finite value. The square root of the Jensen-Shannon divergence is a metric.
      Parameters:
      x - x coord.
      y - y coord.
      Returns:
      Divergence.

    • divergenceKullbackLeibler

      public static double divergenceKullbackLeibler(double[] x, double[] y)
      Kullback-Leibler divergence.The Kullback-Leibler divergence (also information divergence, information gain, relative entropy, or KLIC) is a non-symmetric measure of the difference between two probability distributions P and Q.KL measures the expected number of extra bits required to code samples from P when using a code based on Q, rather than using a code based on P.Typically P represents the "true" distribution of data, observations, or a precise calculated theoretical distribution. The measure Q typically represents a theory, model, description, or approximation of P.

      Although it is often intuited as a distance metric, the KL divergence is not a true metric - for example, the KL from P to Q is not necessarily the same as the KL from Q to P.

      Parameters:
      x - x coord.
      y - y coord.
      Returns:
      Divergence.
